ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Vestibular Schwannoma
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Confirmed by MRI; consistent with asymmetric SNHL, poor word recognition, absent ABR, and unilateral vestibular weakness.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Hereditary Sensorineural Hearing Loss
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Patient has a 10-15 year history of gradual bilateral progressive hearing loss.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Endolymphatic Hydrops
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Considered due to symptoms of fullness, tinnitus, and vertigo, but MRI confirmed tumor.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Labyrinthitis
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Considered initially due to acute vertigo episode, but symptoms persisted.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Autoimmune Inner Ear Disease
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Considered in differential but less likely given the unilateral tumor findings.

ordered_list.rationale_short: Evaluate hearing thresholds given history of progressive loss and recent changes.
Assess word recognition abilities and check for retrocochlear signs (asymmetry).
Evaluate vestibular function due to persistent imbalance.
Assess functional balance and sensory integration.
Confirm retrocochlear pathology given asymmetric findings.
Investigate hyperventilation-induced symptoms and determine if lesion is excitatory.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Audiologic evaluation revealed bilateral sensorineural hearing loss with a 'cookie-bite' configuration. Crucially, there was significant asymmetry with the right ear showing poorer thresholds and disproportionately poor word recognition (8%), along with absent acoustic reflexes. These findings are highly suggestive of retrocochlear pathology.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Right ear: mild sloping to moderate rising to mild SNHL (PTA ~45-50 dB HL). Left ear: slight sloping to moderate rising to normal SNHL. U-shaped configuration.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: Significant asymmetry: Right WRS 8%, Left WRS 100%.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.result_summary: Type A bilateral, normal middle ear function.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.result_summary: Absent in the right ear; present in the left ear.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Initial vestibular evaluation confirmed a right peripheral vestibular deficit. VOG showed significant unilateral weakness, and CDP indicated a backward center of gravity, consistent with the patient's imbalance.

tests.name: Computerized dynamic posturography (CDP)
tests.result_summary: Generally normal except for backward center of gravity.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Follow-up audiology monitoring showed a rapid and severe decline in right ear hearing thresholds and word recognition (dropping to 0%). ABR testing showed absent waveforms on the right, further confirming retrocochlear involvement consistent with the known vestibular schwannoma.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Right ear declined to severe rising to moderately severe SNHL (low freqs ~80-90 dB HL). Left ear stable.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: Right WRS dropped to 0%. Left WRS 88%.

tests.name: Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR)
tests.result_summary: Right ear: Absent waveforms. Left ear: Normal absolute latencies for Waves I, III, V.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Further vestibular testing revealed functional decline on CDP. SVV and VEMP testing indicated right-sided otolith dysfunction, and hyperventilation testing suggested an excitatory lesion.

tests.name: Dynamic Subjective Visual Vertical (SVV)
tests.result_summary: Deviated, consistent with right utricular dysfunction.

tests.name: VEMP
tests.result_summary: Absent or reduced response on the right.

tests.name: Hyperventilation Test
tests.result_summary: Positive for nystagmus, indicating retrocochlear pathology.

proposed_items: Surgical resection (e.g., translabyrinthine approach due to non-serviceable hearing)
Consideration of CROS or BiCROS hearing aid systems
counseling_actions: Discuss surgical risks including facial nerve paralysis and CSF leak
Counsel on expectations for single-sided deafness
Educate on fall prevention strategies due to vestibular weakness

escalation.rationale_short: Confirmed Vestibular Schwannoma with rapid functional decline requires immediate surgical evaluation.

follow_up_plan.timeline: Immediate neurosurgical referral; Post-operative follow-up as dictated by surgery.
follow_up_plan.objective: Tumor removal/control, facial nerve preservation, and vestibular compensation.

expected_outcome: Permanent total hearing loss in the right ear
Gradual compensation of vestibular function with therapy
Control of tumor growth via surgical intervention
